content:
- 2 -
用土福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
C. L. 28.1956
7 November 1956
(a) a comprehensive review of the historical circumstances which led to the establishment of the International Centres by WHO;
(b) a full analysis of the functions of the International Centres and of their functional relationships with WHO, with the International Association of Microbiological Societies, and with National Salmonella Centres and National Shigella Centres ;
(c) a detailed technical statement of the services which the International Centres provide to officially designated National Centres ; and
(d) a body of suggestions which might be useful for the guidance of national health administrations contemplating the selection and designation of a laboratory as their National Salmonella Centre or National Shigella Centre.
It is perhaps hardly necessary for me to mention that the establishment of a National Salmonella Centre and a National Shigella Centre is only one of the activities that a country will develop to investigate, prevent, and treat salmonella and shigella infections. General sanitary and health measures would naturally constitute the main programme, of which the laboratory services provided by these Centres are only one useful component. I am, of course, giving due consideration to the development of the other aspects of work directed against these infections.
I would be grateful if you would be kind enough to forward me the name or names of the laboratory or laboratories which may now be serving as your National Salmonella Centre and National Shigella Centre for the purposes outlined in the attached Annex. If no laboratory has yet been selected and appointed by your Government for these purposes, may I venture to suggest that your Government might consider whether it is yet in a position to make such a selection, in which case I should be glad if you would forward to me, in due course, the name or names of the laboratory or laboratories so appointed. When I have received from you the names either of your existing National Salmonella Centre and National Shigella Centre, or of those which you are now in a position to appoint as such, I will transmit the information to the appropriate International Centres so that direct relations between them and your National Centres may be either reinforced or established, as the case may require.
I trust that the suggestions and observations of pages 15 to 19 of the Annex, under the heading of "Selection and Appointment of National Centres", will be helpful to you in considering the selection of laboratories to serve as your National Salmonella and National Shigella Centres. Among other points you will note the important reasons given on page 15 for the selection of only one officially recognized National Salmonella Centre and only one National Shigella Centre respectively, and not several of each in any one country. Reasons are also given for anticipating that, in many countries, it will be found expedient both for the National Salmonella Centre and the National Shigella Centre to be housed in a single institution.
國史饭 Academia Historica
71

(a) a comprehensive review of the historical circumstances which led to the establishment of the International Centres by WHO;

(b) a full analysis of the functions of the International Centres and of their functional relationships with WHO, with the International Association of Microbiological Societies, and with National Salmonella Centres and National Shigella Centres ;
(c) a detailed technical statement of the services which the International Centres provide to officially designated National Centres ; and

(d) a body of suggestions which might be useful for the guidance of national health administrations contemplating the selection and designation of a laboratory as their National Salmonella Centre or National Shigella Centre.

It is perhaps hardly necessary for me to mention that the establishment of a National Salmonella Centre and a National Shigella Centre is only one of the activities that a country will develop to investigate, prevent, and treat salmonella and shigella infections. General sanitary and health measures would naturally constitute the main programme, of which the laboratory services provided by these Centres are only one useful component. I am, of course, giving due consideration to the development of the other aspects of work directed against these infections.

I would be grateful if you would be kind enough to forward me the name or names of the laboratory or laboratories which may now be serving as your National Salmonella Centre and National Shigella Centre for the purposes outlined in the attached Annex. If no laboratory has yet been selected and appointed by your Government for these purposes, may I venture to suggest that your Government might consider whether it is yet in a position to make such a selection, in which case I should be glad if you would forward to me, in due course, the name or names of the laboratory or laboratories so appointed. When I have received from you the names either of your existing National Salmonella Centre and National Shigella Centre, or of those which you are now in a position to appoint as such, I will transmit the information to the appropriate International Centres so that direct relations between them and your National Centres may be either reinforced or established, as the case may require.

I trust that the suggestions and observations of pages 15 to 19 of the Annex, under the heading of "Selection and Appointment of National Centres", will be helpful to you in considering the selection of laboratories to serve as your National Salmonella and National Shigella Centres. Among other points you will note the important reasons given on page 15 for the selection of only one officially recognized National Salmonella Centre and only one National Shigella Centre respectively, and not several of each in any one country. Reasons are also given for anticipating that, in many countries, it will be found expedient both for the National Salmonella Centre and the National Shigella Centre to be housed in a single institution.
